title: Experian shares fall sharply after T-Mobile data breach
text:
16.15 +0.74 
The stock tumbled after it emerged that the personal details of 15 million customers were hacked 
Experian (Other OTC: EXPGF - news ) , the world’s biggest consumer credit monitoring firm, is poised for its worst trading session in 18 months after it revealed a massive data breach on Thursday night. 
Almost 15 million people, including customers of T-Mobile US who applied for service, were affected. 
The FTSE 100 company discovered the data had been hacked from one of its services on September 15, and Connecticut’s attorney general has since said he will launch an investigation into the matter. 
T-Mobile chief executive John Legere said data stolen related to new applicants who required a credit check for the service or for device financing from September 1 through September 16, and included information such as name, address, date of birth, social security numbers, driver’s licence and passport numbers. 
In a statement on the company's website, Mr Legere said: “Obviously I am incredibly angry about this data breach and will institute a thorough review of our relationship with Experian, but right now my top concern and first focus is assisting any and all consumers affected.” 
However, Mr Legere reassured customers T-Mobile’s systems or network were not part of the intrusion, and the data theft did not involve any payment card numbers or bank account details. 
Although Experian told T-Mobile it had taken “aggressive steps to improve the protection of their system”, the company has suffered data breaches before. 
In 2012, a data attack on a subsidiary of Experian exposed the social security numbers of 200m Americans. * Seven ways to avoid being hacked Analysts at Shore Capital said they already had concerns over the company’s trading performance, particularly its trading conditions in Brazil in the near-term and emerging ‘mobile’ trends. 
Robin Speakman, of Shore Capital, said: “The news overnight from the US that Experian has been hacked in relation to specific services for T-mobile in the country is a further concern. 
“We view this as an important incident, which needs a prompt and strong response and, as much as possible, future prevention.” 
The stock became the biggest the faller in early trade, changing hands at £10.20, down 55p, or 5.1pc - its lowest level since May 2014. * Experian shares jump on solid trading
